awd_titl_txt: High-Dimensional Interaction Detection and Nonparametric Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how variables interact with each other is fundamentally important in many scientific discoveries and contemporary applications, especially in areas such as social networks, marketing, medicine, genetics, and cancer studies. Identifying important interactions can also help improve model interpretability and prediction. Yet interaction detection with high-dimensional data poses great challenges since the number of pairwise interactions increases quadratically with the number of covariates and that of higher-order interactions grows even faster. Although there is a growing literature on interaction detection, there is a limited amount of work on the error rate control and inference aspects. Building robust statistical foundations of interaction detection and nonparametric inference, and offering reproducible and scalable algorithms for selecting important interactions can greatly facilitate the use of these much-needed tools in real applications. The common theme underlying this entire project is that of developing statistical methodologies and theories on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference with statistical guarantees and improved reproducibility and interpretability.


This project has three interrelated aims of timely theoretical and methodological studies on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference. The first aim establishes the theoretical foundation of prediction and false sign rate control for interaction detection in ultra-high dimensional regression models. The second aim builds on the recent development of model-X knockoffs and proposes new methods for high-dimensional interaction detection with false discovery rate control and appealing power. The third aim further investigates the nonlinear interactions between a pair of high-dimensional random vectors and develops a new testing procedure for high-dimensional nonparametric inference through the lens of distance correlation. The systematic research program developed in three aims above will help build rigorous statistical foundations of theory and methodologies for high-dimensional data analysis that can guide practitioners and researchers. The investigators also plan to systematically develop tractable and efficient computation algorithms to implement the proposed methods through free software packages, like R and Python, and then make them readily available and publicize them in all relevant fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award led to various interrelated research projects on rigorous statistical foundations of theory and methodologies for high-dimensional data analysis and data science on reproducibility, nonparametric inference, and causal inference.
Reproducibility in scientific research has become a significant topic because of the abundance of false findings. False discovery rate (FDR) control is one way to alleviate the reproducibility problem, and the knockoff framework offers a systematic and flexible way of ensuring FDR control. One of the projects on reproducibility establishes the theoretical foundation of prediction and false sign rate control for interaction detection in ultra-high dimensional regression models. Another project builds on the recent development of model-X knockoffs and proposes a new method for high-dimensional interaction detection with false discovery rate control and appealing power. The idea behind the knockoff framework is to build a knockoff copy of the original variables. In a third project, we aim to answer how we can create more than one knockoff copy, and if we can make multiple knockoff copies, how we can use them to help us improve the FDR control method. Finally, most research on FDR control is confined to detecting the main effects. On the other hand, contemporary high-dimensional data sets often harbor complex relationships between variables. Therefore, obtaining FDR control results in finding interaction variables is crucial. In another work, we aim to generalize the knockoff framework to encompass interaction detection, allowing FDR control results.
Nonparametric inference:Nonparametric methods are becoming more critical as a result of more complex data sets that require flexible methods. The weighted nearest neighbors (WNN) estimator has been popularly used as a flexible and easy-to-implement nonparametric tool for mean regression estimation. The bagging technique is an elegant way to form WNN estimators with weights automatically generated to the nearest neighbors. We name the resulting estimator as the distributional nearest neighbors. We explored the technical analysis of the distributional nearest neighbor method and used it to derive an improved nearest neighbor estimator called the two-scale distributional nearest neighbor method. We also showed the distributional results for the estimator, enabling its application to statistical inference.
Causal Inference:In estimating causal effects with observational data, many methods (such as regression, matching, and regression continuity) rely on the unconfoundedness assumption. That is, no unobserved variables affect both the treatment variable and outcome variable values. When longitudinal or panel data are available, methods such as fixed effects regression and difference-in-difference can remove unobserved confounding factors that are constant over time. However, the validity of the estimated causal effects still rely on the assumption that there is no time-varying unobserved confounding. The recently developed Synthetic Control Method (SCM) can potentially address the unobserved confounding problem. However, two important assumptions are required. The first is that the number of pre-treatment time periods should be large, and the second is that good pre-treatment matches should exist in the data. In this work, we use Negative Control Outcomes (NCO), a popular tool for detecting bias due to unobserved confounding, to lessen the assumptions of the synthetic control method.

Finally, the aforementioned new statistical methods and tools developed in this project are broadly applicable. They can guide practitioners and researchers on high-dimensional interaction detection and nonparametric inference with statistical guarantees and improved reproducibility and interpretability. These high-dimensional inference methods can be used in many areas, such as social networks, marketing, medicine, genetics, cancer studies, and many other. The methods provide improved model interpretability, reproducibility, and prediction.
